title: Prohibits any person who works on a regular basis for a political committee for a statewide elected office from receiving compensation from an inaugural committee
summary: Prohibits any person who works on a regular basis for a political committee for a statewide elected office from receiving compensation from an inaugural committee.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2280

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the election law, in relation to limitation on compen-
sation by inauguration committees

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
This bill would preclude inauguration committees from paying persons who
worked regularly on political campaigns.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
This bill would add a new section 14-125 to the Election Law, which
would preclude inauguration committees from compensating a person who
worked on a regular basis for the political campaign committee.

JUSTIFICATION:
Campaign fund raising practices are having a corrosive effect on the
public's confidence in the integrity of government. Too often, citizens
feel that their individual votes are of little consequence. The cumula-
tive impact is a significant threat to the fundamental values of democ-
racy. Numerous accounts, have revealed disturbing instances of people
who have worked regularly on a political campaign moving to jobs with an
inauguration committee immediately after an election victory. Inaugu-
ration committees have solicited contributions with the avowed purpose
of defraying expenses that might otherwise be borne by the state for
inaugural activities.  When the inauguration committee pays a former
campaign worker substantial amounts of money, it may be that the
payments are compensating the person for prior campaign work. This bill
addresses the problem by precluding inauguration committees from compen-
sating persons who worked on a regular basis for the political campaign
committee.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS FOR STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act takes effect immediately.
